pico.title: Privacy-Preserving Computation for Cross-Border Earth Observation Data Sharing: A Scoping Review
pico.population: Satellite-derived environmental monitoring data requiring cross-border sharing for regional and global analysis, including transboundary deforestation monitoring, shared watershed water quality assessment, cross-border air pollution tracking, migratory species monitoring, regional climate analysis, and disaster response coordination across national boundaries
pico.intervention: Privacy-preserving computation approaches enabling joint analysis without raw data transfer, including secure multi-party computation (MPC/SMPC), trusted execution environments (TEEs/secure enclaves), homomorphic encryption (FHE, PHE), federated analytics, and differential privacy for cross-border aggregates
pico.comparison: Traditional data sharing via bilateral agreements and data transfer, federated analysis without cryptographic protection, analysis restricted to national boundaries only, and trusted third-party data intermediaries
pico.outcome: Analytical capability for transboundary environmental assessments (accuracy, completeness, timeliness), compliance with data sovereignty requirements and national legislation, computational feasibility (latency, cost, scalability), trust establishment and governance complexity, and operational sustainability
pico.research_question: For transboundary environmental monitoring requiring satellite data from multiple jurisdictions, how do cryptographic privacy-preserving computation approaches compare to traditional data sharing mechanisms in enabling regional analysis while respecting data sovereignty requirements?
pico.rationale: Environmental challenges do not respect national borders: the Amazon spans 9 countries, major river basins cross multiple jurisdictions, air pollution flows across frontiers, and migratory species traverse continents. Effective monitoring requires combining satellite observations from multiple national sources. However, data sovereignty laws increasingly restrict cross-border data flows, and national agencies may be unwilling to share raw observations for security, commercial, or political reasons. Privacy-preserving computation offers a potential technical solution enabling joint analysis without data transfer, but evidence on practical effectiveness for EO applications remains limited.

sub_questions.title: Secure Multi-Party Computation for EO Analytics
sub_questions.population: Multi-country satellite data analysis scenarios (shared watersheds, transboundary forests, regional air quality)
sub_questions.intervention: Secure multi-party computation protocols for satellite image statistics and derived products
sub_questions.comparison: Different MPC frameworks (SPDZ, ABY, MP-SPDZ); MPC vs. centralized trusted third party
sub_questions.outcome: Computational overhead, communication costs, accuracy vs. centralized computation, practical latency for time-sensitive applications
sub_questions.research_question: How practical is secure multi-party computation for cross-border satellite data analysis in terms of computational overhead and latency?

sub_questions.title: Trusted Execution Environments for Satellite Data
sub_questions.population: Satellite imagery requiring processing in a neutral trusted environment
sub_questions.intervention: TEE-based processing (Intel SGX, ARM TrustZone, AMD SEV) for satellite data analytics
sub_questions.comparison: TEE vs. MPC vs. traditional trusted third party; different TEE platforms
sub_questions.outcome: Processing performance, trust model requirements, attestation and verification complexity, vulnerability to side-channel attacks
sub_questions.research_question: Can trusted execution environments provide practical privacy guarantees for cross-border satellite data processing, and what are the trust assumptions and limitations?

sub_questions.title: Governance and Trust Frameworks
sub_questions.population: International environmental monitoring initiatives requiring multi-country satellite data (GEO, CEOS, regional agreements)
sub_questions.intervention: Technical-legal governance frameworks combining privacy-preserving computation with international agreements
sub_questions.comparison: Pure technical solutions vs. pure legal frameworks vs. combined technical-legal approaches
sub_questions.outcome: Participation rates, time to operational deployment, dispute resolution effectiveness, long-term sustainability
sub_questions.research_question: What governance frameworks most effectively combine privacy-preserving computation technologies with international agreements to enable sustained cross-border environmental monitoring?

stakeholders: Regional environmental bodies (EU Environment Agency, ASEAN)
